The result is hundreds are waiting on the Mexican side in tents. Some, too desperate to wait, are making the dangerous trip across the Rio Grande river.

Until recently, hundreds of undocumented migrants seeking asylum and attempting to cross here were becoming backed up in the @CBP office on the U.S. side. Now, @CBP has instituted â€œmetering,â€ which means only 20 asylum seekers per day are being let through.

The international bridge at the Brownsville Port of Entry. The white awning is U.S. territory. The green awning is Mexican territory. People cross back and forth all day â€“ by the hundreds â€“ if their visas and day passes are in order. pic.twitter.com/ofdW6AiF50

Cocaine was found in this gas tank coming across the bridge at the Brownsville Port of Entry. Most contraband that comes into the U.S. comes through official ports of entry. pic.twitter.com/SDnE08VF5p
At the Brownsville Port of Entry from Mexico into the U.S., where we received a briefing from Director Higgerson of the @CBP. pic.twitter.com/qjKoVvLr3S

.@CBP has a good relationship with Sister Normaâ€™s @CCharitiesRGV center, so it releases families to the center and from there, they set out on a journey to sponsors. Preparing to enter the McAllen Centralized Processing Center known as â€œUrsula.â€ Masks are required to protect against the flu and other outbreaks that have occurred, including bacterial meningitis. pic.twitter.com/JJOagCKDuD

This interpreter is talking to a detainee who indicated that there are dozens in a cell meant to hold ten people and many detainees have been there for more than three weeks. pic.twitter.com/oXmS4h6lIE

These migrants are not being sent to the next stage of the process â€“ @ICEgov facilities that can accommodate them for longer periods of time pending adjudication â€“ because ICE is over capacity. These detainees are living for weeks in cells that are only meant for 72-hour holding. pic.twitter.com/oiZVb0VIcy
